title: Transtubular Potassium Gradient (TTKG)
description: Evaluates renal potassium handling in patients with hyperkalemia or hypokalemia by estimating the ratio of potassium in the cortical collecting duct to that in the peritubular capillaries.

ranges.interpretation: TTKG values between 8 and 9 are considered normal in patients with a normal diet.

ranges.description: Normal renal K+ excretion in hyperkalemia
ranges.interpretation: During hyperkalemia (K+ >5.0 mEq/L), TTKG ≥7 indicates appropriate renal potassium excretion. Expected TTKG >10 suggests optimal renal response.
During hyperkalemia (K+ >5.0 mEq/L), TTKG <7 suggests hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance, indicating impaired renal potassium excretion.
During hypokalemia (K+ <3.5 mEq/L), TTKG <3 indicates appropriate renal potassium conservation.
During hypokalemia (K+ <3.5 mEq/L), TTKG ≥3 suggests renal potassium wasting, indicating inappropriate urinary potassium losses.

references: Ethier JH, Kamel KS, Magner PO, Lemann J Jr, Halperin ML. The transtubular potassium concentration in patients with hypokalemia and hyperkalemia. Am J Kidney Dis. 1990 Apr;15(4):309-15.
Choi MJ, Ziyadeh FN. The utility of the transtubular potassium gradient in the evaluation of hyperkalemia. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2008 Mar;19(3):424-6.
Kamel KS, Halperin ML. Intrarenal urea recycling leads to a higher rate of renal excretion of potassium: an hypothesis with clinical implications. Curr Opin Nephrol Hypertens. 2011 Sep;20(5):547-54.
formula: TTKG = (Urine K × Serum osmolality) / (Serum K × Urine osmolality)
notes: TTKG is only valid when urine osmolality exceeds serum osmolality
Urine sodium should be >25 mmol/L for accurate interpretation
The formula assumes that potassium is neither secreted nor reabsorbed in the medullary collecting duct
TTKG has been criticized for potential inaccuracy, particularly in hyperkalemia evaluation
Should be interpreted in clinical context and not used as the sole decision-making tool
